Vocabulary.mean: When someone is afraid, they feel fear.
Vocabulary.example: The woman was afraid of what she saw.

Vocabulary.mean: To agree is to say “yes” or to think the same way.
Vocabulary.example: A: The food is very good in that restaurant. B: I agree with you.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is angry, they may want to speak loudly or fight.
Vocabulary.example: She didn’t do her homework, so her father is angry.

Vocabulary.mean: To arrive is to get to or reach some place.
Vocabulary.example: The bus always arrives at the corner of my street at 4:00.

Vocabulary.mean: To attack is to try to fight or to hurt.
Vocabulary.example: The man with the sword attacked the other man first.

Vocabulary.mean: The bottom is the lowest part.
Vocabulary.example: The bottom of my shoe has a hole in it.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is clever, they can solve a hard puzzle or problem.
Vocabulary.example: The clever boy thought of a good idea.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is cruel, they do bad things to hurt others.
Vocabulary.example: The cruel man yelled at his sister.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens finally, it happens after a longtime or at the end.
Vocabulary.example: He finally crossed the finish line after five hours of running.

Vocabulary.mean: To hide is to try not to let others see you.
Vocabulary.example: The other children will hide while you count to 100

Vocabulary.mean: To hunt is to look for or search for an animal to kill.
Vocabulary.example: Long ago, people hunted with bows and arrows.

Vocabulary.mean: A lot means a large number or amount of people, animals, things, etc.
Vocabulary.example: There are a lot of apples in the basket.

Vocabulary.mean: The middle of something is the center or halfway point.
Vocabulary.example: The Canadian flag has a maple leaf in the middle of it.

Vocabulary.mean: A moment is a second or a very short time.
Vocabulary.example: I was only a few moments late for the meeting.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is pleased, they are happy.
Vocabulary.example: She was pleased with the phone call she received.

Vocabulary.mean: To promise is to say you will do something for sure.
Vocabulary.example: He promised to return my key by tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: To reply is to give an answer or say back to someone.
Vocabulary.example: She asked him what time his meeting was. He replied, “at three.”

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is safe, they are not in danger.
Vocabulary.example: Put on your seat belt in the car to be safe.

Vocabulary.mean: A trick is something you do to fool another person.
Vocabulary.example: His card trick really surprised us.

Vocabulary.mean: You use well to say that something was done in a good way.
Vocabulary.example: The couple can dance quite well.

Vocabulary.mean: An adventure is a fun or exciting thing that you do.
Vocabulary.example: Riding in the rough water was an adventure.

Vocabulary.mean: To approach something means to move close to it.
Vocabulary.example: The boy approached his school.

Vocabulary.mean: Carefully means with great attention, especially to detail or safety.
Vocabulary.example: The baby carefully climbed down the stairs.

Vocabulary.mean: A chemical is something that scientists use in chemistry.
Vocabulary.example: The scientist mixed the chemicals.

Vocabulary.mean: To create means to make something new.
Vocabulary.example: She created an igloo from blocks of snow.

Vocabulary.mean: Evil describes something or someone bad or cruel, not good.
Vocabulary.example: The evil figure scared us all.

Vocabulary.mean: An experiment is a test that you do to see what will happen.
Vocabulary.example: The student did an experiment in science class.

Vocabulary.mean: To kill someone or something is to make them die.
Vocabulary.example: I killed the fly with a fly swatter.

Vocabulary.mean: A laboratory is a room where a scientist works.
Vocabulary.example: My mother works in a laboratory.

Vocabulary.mean: Laugh is the sound made when someone is happy or a funny thing occurs
Vocabulary.example: The sound of their laugh filled the room.

Vocabulary.mean: If a sound is loud, it is strong and very easy to hear.
Vocabulary.example: The man’s voice was so loud that we all could hear him.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is nervous, they think something bad will happen.
Vocabulary.example: The boy became nervous when he heard the news.

Vocabulary.mean: A noise is an unpleasant sound.
Vocabulary.example: The crying baby made a loud noise.

Vocabulary.mean: A project is a type of work that you do for school or a job.
Vocabulary.example: His afternoon work project was to paint the room green.

Vocabulary.mean: To scare someone is to make them feel afraid.
Vocabulary.example: My uncle was scared by what he saw in the room.

Vocabulary.mean: A secret is something that you do not tell other people.
Vocabulary.example: The two boys were sharing a secret.

Vocabulary.mean: To shout is to say something loudly.
Vocabulary.example: My boss shouted at me because I was late for work.

Vocabulary.mean: To smell something means to use your nose to sense it.
Vocabulary.example: The two friends smelled the flower.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is terrible, it is very bad.
Vocabulary.example: The way he treated his classmate was terrible.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worse, it is of poorer quality than another thing.
Vocabulary.example: Business was worse this month than last month.

Vocabulary.mean: An alien is a creature from a different world.
Vocabulary.example: The alien came in peace.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are among certain things, they are all around you.
Vocabulary.example: There was a red apple among the green ones.

Vocabulary.mean: A chart is a list of information.
Vocabulary.example: We used a chart to see how we had improved.

Vocabulary.mean: A cloud is a group of water drops in the sky.
Vocabulary.example: The sky was filled with white clouds.

Vocabulary.mean: To comprehend something is to understand it.
Vocabulary.example: Henry could not comprehend the message.

Vocabulary.mean: To describe is to say or write what someone or something is like.
Vocabulary.example: They described their tree as colorful with gold ribbon and a star.

Vocabulary.mean: Ever means at any time.
Vocabulary.example: Going skiing last winter was the most fun I’ve ever had.

Vocabulary.mean: To fail means you do not succeed in what you try to do.
Vocabulary.example: Since he failed to get the job, he was sad.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendly is behaving in a pleasant, kind way toward someone.
Vocabulary.example: The friendly animals came up to the girl.

Vocabulary.mean: A grade is a score or mark given to someone’s work.
Vocabulary.example: I managed to get good grades on my report card.

Vocabulary.mean: Instead means in place of.
Vocabulary.example: He ate the carrot instead of the ice cream.

Vocabulary.mean: A library is a place where you go to read books.
Vocabulary.example: The library at school is full of books.

Vocabulary.mean: A planet is a large round thing in space.
Vocabulary.example: Saturn is the planet with the ring around it.

Vocabulary.mean: A report is something students write for school.
Vocabulary.example: Karen had trouble writing her report.

Vocabulary.mean: Several is more than two but not many.
Vocabulary.example: He had to read several books for class.

Vocabulary.mean: To solve something is to find an answer to it.
Vocabulary.example: All the students could easily solve the math problem.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens suddenly, it happens quickly and unexpectedly.
Vocabulary.example: I was suddenly surprised by the cake my friends brought me.

Vocabulary.mean: To suppose is to guess.
Vocabulary.example: I suppose I should go home now.

Vocabulary.mean: The universe is the known or supposed objects in space.
Vocabulary.example: The universe is so large that it cannot be measured.

Vocabulary.mean: To view is to look at something.
Vocabulary.example: Michael likes to view himself in the mirror.

Vocabulary.mean: When a thing is appropriate, it is right or normal.
Vocabulary.example: It’s appropriate to wear a suit when you go to the office.

Vocabulary.mean: To avoid something is to stay away from it.
Vocabulary.example: Avoid the broken bottle on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To behave is to act in a particular way, especially to be good.
Vocabulary.example: She always behaves well when her father is around.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is calm, they do not get excited or upset.
Vocabulary.example: A nice warm bath makes me feel so calm.

Vocabulary.mean: Concern is a feeling of worry.
Vocabulary.example: I was filled with concern after reading the newspaper.

Vocabulary.mean: To be content is to be happy and not want more.
Vocabulary.example: The baby looked very content sitting on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: If you expect something to happen, you believe it will happen.
Vocabulary.example: I expect the bus to be here very soon.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happens frequently, it happens often.
Vocabulary.example: We meet frequently, either at the beginning or ending of the week.

Vocabulary.mean: A habit is a thing that you do often.
Vocabulary.example: Smoking is a bad habit that can kill you.

Vocabulary.mean: To instruct is to teach.
Vocabulary.example: My teacher instructs us in several subjects.

Vocabulary.mean: An issue is an important topic.
Vocabulary.example: The men spoke about issues that were important to the people.

Vocabulary.mean: None means not any of someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: He spent all his money. There is none left.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is patient, they don’t become angry or upset easily.
Vocabulary.example: I had to be patient and wait until 5 o’clock to leave.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is positive, it is good.
Vocabulary.example: She has a positive future ahead of her after finishing college.

Vocabulary.mean: To punish means to make someone suffer for breaking the rules or laws.
Vocabulary.example: To punish me, my teacher had me stand in the corner.

Vocabulary.mean: To represent is to speak or act for a person or group.
Vocabulary.example: My lawyer will represent me in court.

Vocabulary.mean: To shake is to move back and forth or up and down quickly.
Vocabulary.example: When people shake hands, it usually means they agree.

Vocabulary.mean: To spread is to move quickly to more places.
Vocabulary.example: I like to spread butter on my toast.

Vocabulary.mean: To stroll means to walk slowly and calmly.
Vocabulary.example: My dog and I strolled through the park today.

Vocabulary.mean: A village is a very small town.
Vocabulary.example: There are only a few houses in my village.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are aware of something, you know about it.
Vocabulary.example: I was not aware of the ringing phone.

Vocabulary.mean: Badly means in a severe or harmful way.
Vocabulary.example: He hurt his arm badly playing with friends.

Vocabulary.mean: If something belongs to you, you own it.
Vocabulary.example: The blue suit belongs to Paul.

Vocabulary.mean: To continue something is to keep doing it.
Vocabulary.example: She stood under her umbrella as the rain continued to fall.

Vocabulary.mean: An error is something you do wrong.
Vocabulary.example: made an error on my report, so my boss was angry.

Vocabulary.mean: An experience is something you have seen or done.
Vocabulary.example: Rock climbing was a fun experience.

Vocabulary.mean: A field is a big area of land.
Vocabulary.example: The field of flowers looked so pretty.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurt is to do something that makes you feel pain.
Vocabulary.example: She hurt her leg falling down the stairs.

Vocabulary.mean: Judgment is the ability to form opinions or decisions.
Vocabulary.example: It’s good judgment to recycle your aluminum cans.

Vocabulary.mean: If something likely happens, it will probably happen.
Vocabulary.example: I will likely stay at home and watch TV tonight.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is normal, it is not strange nor surprising to you.
Vocabulary.example: It is normal for me to bathe every night.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is rare, you do not see it very often.
Vocabulary.example: It is rare for him to miss his flight.

Vocabulary.mean: To relax is to rest.
Vocabulary.example: The frog relaxed in the warm sun.

Vocabulary.mean: To request something is to ask for it.
Vocabulary.example: The little girl requested a special gift from Santa Claus.

Vocabulary.mean: To reside means to live somewhere permanently or for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: My brother and his family reside in a lovely house on the beach.

Vocabulary.mean: A result is something that happens because of something else.
Vocabulary.example: Asa result of all the rain, the man had to climb on the roof.

Vocabulary.mean: To roll is to move by turning over and over.
Vocabulary.example: You must roll the ball into the pins when you bowl.

Vocabulary.mean: Since is used to talk about a past event still happening now.
Vocabulary.example: Since 1992, he has been driving that car.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is visible, it can be seen.
Vocabulary.example: The moon and stars were visible in the night sky.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wild, it is found in nature.
Vocabulary.example: You should be careful around a fox, because it is a wild animal.

Vocabulary.mean: An advantage is something that helps you.
Vocabulary.example: Being tall is an advantage to a basketball player.

Vocabulary.mean: To cause is to make something happen.
Vocabulary.example: The cold weather caused her to get sick.

Vocabulary.mean: A choice is the act or possibility of picking something.
Vocabulary.example: I had my choice of five doors to open.

Vocabulary.mean: A community is a group of people who live together.
Vocabulary.example: The kids from my community usually play together.

Vocabulary.mean: To be dead is to not be alive.
Vocabulary.example: A dead person is usually buried in the ground.

Vocabulary.mean: The distance between two things is how far it is between them.
Vocabulary.example: The distance between the Earth and the Moon is 384,400 kilometers.

Vocabulary.mean: To escape is to run away from something bad.
Vocabulary.example: The butterfly could not escape from the cage.

Vocabulary.mean: If you face a problem, you deal with it.
Vocabulary.example: My sister and I have to find a better way to face our differences.

Vocabulary.mean: To follow means to go behind someone and go where they go.
Vocabulary.example: The little boy followed his mother home.

Vocabulary.mean: Fright is the feeling of being scared.
Vocabulary.example: She was filled with fright.

Vocabulary.mean: A ghost is the spirit of a dead person.
Vocabulary.example: Many people are afraid of ghosts.

Vocabulary.mean: An individual is one person.
Vocabulary.example: Only one individual could win the bicycle race.

Vocabulary.mean: A pet is an animal that lives with people.
Vocabulary.example: Out of all my pets, the dog is my favorite.

Vocabulary.mean: To reach means to arrive at a place.
Vocabulary.example: I was happy to finally reach my destination.

Vocabulary.mean: To return is to go back to a place.
Vocabulary.example: I was happy to return home to my mom after school.

Vocabulary.mean: To survive is to stay alive.
Vocabulary.example: dog survived her fall into the water.

Vocabulary.mean: To be upset is to be unhappy about something.
Vocabulary.example: She was upset because she broke her toy.

Vocabulary.mean: A voice is the sound a person makes when they talk or sing.
Vocabulary.example: He used a microphone, so everyone could hear his voice.

Vocabulary.mean: The weather is the condition of the air: hot, rainy, windy, etc.
Vocabulary.example: The weather can be sunny, rainy, or cold.

Vocabulary.mean: To be wise is to use experience and intelligence to make good choices.
Vocabulary.example: Many people believe that owls are very wise animals.

Vocabulary.mean: To allow something to happen means to let it happen.
Vocabulary.example: Having a ticket will allow you to enter the show.

Vocabulary.mean: To announce something is to make it known.
Vocabulary.example: He announced to everyone his new idea for the company.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is beside you, they are next to you.
Vocabulary.example: The two brothers stood beside each other.

Vocabulary.mean: A challenge is something difficult to complete.
Vocabulary.example: It was a challenge to climb to the top of the mountain.

Vocabulary.mean: To claim means to say that something is true.
Vocabulary.example: He claimed to know why the country’s laws were weak.

Vocabulary.mean: The condition of someone or something is the state that they are in.
Vocabulary.example: The patient’s condition was very good.

Vocabulary.mean: To contribute to something means to do something to make it successful
Vocabulary.example: We decided to contribute money to the new hospital.

Vocabulary.mean: A difference is a way that something is not like other things.
Vocabulary.example: The biggest difference between the birds is the color of their feathers.

Vocabulary.mean: To divide something is to make it into smaller parts.
Vocabulary.example: We divided the pizza.

Vocabulary.mean: An expert is someone who is very good at doing something.
Vocabulary.example: The wizard was an expert at magic.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is famous, they are known to many people.
Vocabulary.example: The Eiffel Tower in Paris is very famous.

Vocabulary.mean: Force is a person’s strength or power.
Vocabulary.example: He used all his force to try and open the door.

Vocabulary.mean: Harm is hurt or problems caused to someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: A hot iron can cause great harm if you are not careful

Vocabulary.mean: To lay means to put or place in a horizontal or flat position.
Vocabulary.example: Don’t lay your socks on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: Peace is a time without war.
Vocabulary.example: A white dove is a symbol for peace.

Vocabulary.mean: A prince is the son of a king.
Vocabulary.example: The prince and the princess were married.

Vocabulary.mean: To protect someone is to stop them from getting hurt.
Vocabulary.example: Firemen protect us from fires.

Vocabulary.mean: To sense something is to know about it without being told.
Vocabulary.example: I could sense that he was watching me.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is sudden, it happens very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: He felt a sudden pain in his chest.

Vocabulary.mean: Therefore means for this reason.
Vocabulary.example: He is fat. Therefore, he will go on a diet.

Vocabulary.mean: To accept something that is offered is to take it.
Vocabulary.example: I accepted the girl’s very nice gift.

Vocabulary.mean: To arrange things is to put them in the right place.
Vocabulary.example: Please arrange the bowling pins in order so we can play.

Vocabulary.mean: To attend something is to go to it.
Vocabulary.example: My sister and I attend the same school.

Vocabulary.mean: To balance something is to keep it from falling.
Vocabulary.example: We saw an elephant balance itself on a ball.

Vocabulary.mean: A contrast is the sharp difference between two things.
Vocabulary.example: The contrast between my parents is very noticeable.

Vocabulary.mean: To encourage someone is to make them want to do something.
Vocabulary.example: My football coach will encourage us when we are losing.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is familiar to you, you know them well.
Vocabulary.example: The two friends were very familiar with each other.

Vocabulary.mean: To grab is to take a hold of someone or something suddenly.
Vocabulary.example: I grabbed a pear from the tree.

Vocabulary.mean: To hang something is to keep it above the ground.
Vocabulary.example: I drew a picture of my family, and my mother hung it on the wall.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is huge, it is very big.
Vocabulary.example: At work, my father drives a huge truck

Vocabulary.mean: If something is necessary, you must do it.
Vocabulary.example: It is necessary to have a passport when you travel to a foreign country.

Vocabulary.mean: A pattern is a way in which something is done or organized.
Vocabulary.example: My pattern of brushing my teeth is the same as most people’s.

Vocabulary.mean: To propose something is to say that it should be done.
Vocabulary.example: Santa Claus proposed that I try to be a good boy all year.

Vocabulary.mean: A purpose is the reason that you do something.
Vocabulary.example: The purpose of exercising is to get into shape.

Vocabulary.mean: To release something is to stop holding it.
Vocabulary.example: She released the bird from her hands.

Vocabulary.mean: To require something is to say that it is necessary.
Vocabulary.example: We require teachers to have a university degree.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is single, then there is only one.
Vocabulary.example: I have a single key in my hand.

Vocabulary.mean: Success is doing something well that you choose to do.
Vocabulary.example: My daughter was a big success at school.

Vocabulary.mean: To tear something means to pull it apart.
Vocabulary.example: It is easy to tear paper.

Vocabulary.mean: A theory is an idea about how something works.
Vocabulary.example: We talked about Einstein’s theory of relativity in class.

Vocabulary.mean: To be against something is to be touching it or opposed to it.
Vocabulary.example: They both leaned against the wall.

Vocabulary.mean: The beach is a sandy or rocky place by the ocean.
Vocabulary.example: The little girl built a sandcastle on the beach.

Vocabulary.mean: To damage something is to break it.
Vocabulary.example: The car was damaged in the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To discover something is to find it for the first time.
Vocabulary.example: I discovered some new information in this book!

Vocabulary.mean: An emotion is how you feel.
Vocabulary.example: Anger is a common emotion that we all feel.

Vocabulary.mean: To fix something is to make it work.
Vocabulary.example: My dad has many tools to help him fix broken things.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are frank, you are being very honest.
Vocabulary.example: The teacher had a frank discussion with her students.

Vocabulary.mean: To identify something is to be able to name it.
Vocabulary.example: I used the file to identify his name.

Vocabulary.mean: An island is land in the middle of water.
Vocabulary.example: japan is a group of islands.

Vocabulary.mean: The ocean is all of the salt water that surrounds land.
Vocabulary.example: The ocean can make powerful waves.

Vocabulary.mean: Perhaps is used when you say that something could happen.
Vocabulary.example: Perhaps I will eat an apple for lunch.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is pleasant, you enjoy it.
Vocabulary.example: The character had a pleasant look on its face.

Vocabulary.mean: To prevent something is to stop it from happening.
Vocabulary.example: The handcuffs prevented me from moving my hands.

Vocabulary.mean: A rock is a hard thing in the dirt.
Vocabulary.example: I stacked rocks on top of one another.

Vocabulary.mean: To save something is to keep it from being hurt.
Vocabulary.example: I want to help save the world.

Vocabulary.mean: To step is to walk.
Vocabulary.example: Be careful where you step.

Vocabulary.mean: Still is used when you say that a situation keeps going on.
Vocabulary.example: They are still waiting in line to get tickets.

Vocabulary.mean: A taste is the flavor something makes in your mouth.
Vocabulary.example: The taste of the fruit was sweet.

Vocabulary.mean: To throw something is to use your hand to make it go through the air.
Vocabulary.example: The pitcher can throw the baseball very fast.

Vocabulary.mean: A wave is a line of water that moves higher than the rest of the water.
Vocabulary.example: The water was filled with large blue waves.

Vocabulary.mean: A benefit is a good thing.
Vocabulary.example: Being able to fly is a good benefit to birds.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are certain about something, you know it is true.
Vocabulary.example: I am certain that zebras have stripes.

Vocabulary.mean: A chance is an opportunity to do something.
Vocabulary.example: I had a chance to see the Roman Coliseum last summer.

Vocabulary.mean: An effect is a change made by something else.
Vocabulary.example: The medicine had a good effect on the boy.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is essential, it is very important and necessary.
Vocabulary.example: It is essential to have oxygen when you scuba dive.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is far, it is not close.
Vocabulary.example: It's not far to the beach.

Vocabulary.mean: To focus on something is to think about it and pay attention to it.
Vocabulary.example: My mom always helps me to focus on my school work.

Vocabulary.mean: The function of something is what it does.
Vocabulary.example: The function of the heart is to pump blood through the body.

Vocabulary.mean: Grass is the green leaves that cover the ground.
Vocabulary.example: Don't walk on the grass.

Vocabulary.mean: To guard something is to take care of it.
Vocabulary.example: The police officer will guard us from any harm.

Vocabulary.mean: The image of something is a picture of it.
Vocabulary.example: The image of her eye was very clear.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is immediate, it happens quickly.
Vocabulary.example: An immediate response came from the pizza place.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is primary, it is the most important thing.
Vocabulary.example: His primary thoughts are about money.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone feels proud, they are happy about what they have done.
Vocabulary.example: She is proud of the picture she drew of her house.

Vocabulary.mean: To remain somewhere is to stay there.
Vocabulary.example: My sister had to remain home since she was sick.

Vocabulary.mean: To rest is to stop being active while the body gets back its strength.
Vocabulary.example: I rested on the couch after work.

Vocabulary.mean: If two things are separate, they are not together.
Vocabulary.example: New York and Los Angeles are in two separate parts of America.

Vocabulary.mean: A site is a place.
Vocabulary.example: We found the perfect site for our picnic.

Vocabulary.mean: A tail is a part of an animal’s body, sticking out from its rear or back.
Vocabulary.example: Our dog wags its tail when it’s happy.

Vocabulary.mean: Trouble is a problem ora difficulty.
Vocabulary.example: I have trouble working with my boss.

Vocabulary.mean: Anymore means any longer.
Vocabulary.example: Her old pants don’t fit her anymore.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is asleep, they are not awake.
Vocabulary.example: The baby has been asleep for hours.

Vocabulary.mean: A berry is a small round fruit that grows on certain plants and trees.
Vocabulary.example: The berry looked delicious.

Vocabulary.mean: To collect things is to group them together all in one place.
Vocabulary.example: I collected shells when I was younger.

Vocabulary.mean: To compete is to try to be better than someone.
Vocabulary.example: He will compete with very good athletes.

Vocabulary.mean: A conversation is a talk between people.
Vocabulary.example: There were two conversations going on at once.

Vocabulary.mean: A creature is any living thing.
Vocabulary.example: The creature we saw today was either a dolphin or a porpoise

Vocabulary.mean: A decision is a choice.
Vocabulary.example: He made the wrong decision.

Vocabulary.mean: Either is used with “or” to say there are two or more possibilities.
Vocabulary.example: You can choose to be either white or black when you play chess.

Vocabulary.mean: A forest is a place with lots of trees and animals.
Vocabulary.example: I love to go walking in the forest.

Vocabulary.mean: The ground is the top part of the Earth that we walk on.
Vocabulary.example: The ground under our feet was dry and brown.

Vocabulary.mean: To introduce someone or something is to say who they are.
Vocabulary.example: I introduced myself to our newest cotoday.

Vocabulary.mean: To marry is to legally become husband and wife.
Vocabulary.example: Rose and Henry were married, and they lived happily.

Vocabulary.mean: To prepare is to get ready for something.
Vocabulary.example: I prepared my speech to the class.

Vocabulary.mean: To sail is to move a boat on the water.
Vocabulary.example: I love to sail my boat on the lake.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is serious, it is bad or unsafe.
Vocabulary.example: The accident was very serious.

Vocabulary.mean: To spend is to use time doing something or being somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: I like to spend my free time fishing.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is strange, it is not normal.
Vocabulary.example: Joe had a strange look on his face after he saw what happened.

Vocabulary.mean: The truth is a fact or something that is right.
Vocabulary.example: He was telling the truth about seeing a large green snake.

Vocabulary.mean: To wake is to not be sleeping anymore.
Vocabulary.example: He is always full of energy when he wakes in the morning.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is alone, they are not with another person.
Vocabulary.example: The boy wanted to be alone to think.

Vocabulary.mean: An apartment is a set of rooms in a building where people live.
Vocabulary.example: She has a nice apartment in the city.

Vocabulary.mean: An article is a story in a newspaper or magazine.
Vocabulary.example: Did you read the article in the newspaper about the soccer game?

Vocabulary.mean: An artist is a person who paints, draws, or makes sculptures.
Vocabulary.example: He went to Paris to become an artist.

Vocabulary.mean: Someone’s attitude is the way they feel and think.
Vocabulary.example: John has a bad attitude. He’s always angry.

Vocabulary.mean: To compare means to say how two things are the same and different.
Vocabulary.example: We compared the two reports carefully.

Vocabulary.mean: To judge something is to say if it is good or bad.
Vocabulary.example: The boy was going to judge how his mother’s turkey tasted.

Vocabulary.mean: A magazine is a regular publication with news, stories, and articles.
Vocabulary.example: She likes to read fashion magazines.

Vocabulary.mean: A material is what is used to make something.
Vocabulary.example: Brick is a good material for building houses.

Vocabulary.mean: A meal is a time when food is eaten like breakfast, lunch, or dinner.
Vocabulary.example: Breakfast is my favorite meal because I enjoy breakfast foods.

Vocabulary.mean: A method is the way to do something.
Vocabulary.example: One method to remember things is to tie a string around your finger.

Vocabulary.mean: A neighbor is a person who lives near you.
Vocabulary.example: I like my neighbor because he’s very friendly.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is professional, it deals with work that uses special skills.
Vocabulary.example: If you want to be a pilot, you must have professional training.

Vocabulary.mean: A profit is the extra money you make when you sell something.
Vocabulary.example: I made a small profit from selling my old clothes.

Vocabulary.mean: The quality of something is how good it is.
Vocabulary.example: The quality of his car is very good.

Vocabulary.mean: A shape is a simple form like a square or circle.
Vocabulary.example: The triangle is my favorite shape.

Vocabulary.mean: A space is an empty area.
Vocabulary.example: I don’t have much space for things in my small house.

Vocabulary.mean: Stairs are the things that are used to go up in a building.
Vocabulary.example: You can take the stairs to the second floor.

Vocabulary.mean: A symbol is a thing that stands for something else.
Vocabulary.example: This symbol tells us that we cannot smoke in this area.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is thin, they are not fat.
Vocabulary.example: The man was thin because he didn’t eat much.

Vocabulary.mean: Blood is the red liquid in your body.
Vocabulary.example: I cut my finger and got blood on my shirt.

Vocabulary.mean: To burn something is to set it on fire.
Vocabulary.example: I burned some wood in the camp fire.

Vocabulary.mean: A cell is a small room where a person is locked in.
Vocabulary.example: The jail cell was very small.

Vocabulary.mean: To contain something is to have it inside.
Vocabulary.example: The mailbox contained a letter.

Vocabulary.mean: To be correct is to be right.
Vocabulary.example: All of my answers on the test were correct.

Vocabulary.mean: A crop is food that a farmer grows.
Vocabulary.example: Wheat is a crop that is made into bread.

Vocabulary.mean: To demand something is to say strongly that you want it.
Vocabulary.example: The workers demanded to be paid more money.

Vocabulary.mean: To be equal is to be the same.
Vocabulary.example: Both students are equal in age.

Vocabulary.mean: To feed is to give food.
Vocabulary.example: Mother feeds my baby brother everyday.

Vocabulary.mean: A hole is an opening in something.
Vocabulary.example: The man was going to jump into the hole in the ice.

Vocabulary.mean: To increase something is to make it larger or more.
Vocabulary.example: They’ve increased the price of gas by 15 cents!

Vocabulary.mean: Long ago, a lord was a man in charge of a town.
Vocabulary.example: The lord of the town was not kind.

Vocabulary.mean: To owe is to have to pay or give back something received from another.
Vocabulary.example: I owed him twenty dollars, so I paid him back.

Vocabulary.mean: A position is the way something is placed.
Vocabulary.example: How can you sit in that position?

Vocabulary.mean: To raise something is to lift it up.
Vocabulary.example: We had to work together to raise the last piece.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is responsible, they do the right things.
Vocabulary.example: I try to be responsible and save money.

Vocabulary.mean: A sight is something interesting to see.
Vocabulary.example: I saw the pyramids of Egypt. What a sight!

Vocabulary.mean: A spot is a place where something happens.
Vocabulary.example: The kitchen is a good spot to eat meals.

Vocabulary.mean: A structure is a building.
Vocabulary.example: They just built a beautiful new structure downtown.

Vocabulary.mean: Whole means all of something.
Vocabulary.example: I ate the whole pie. We don’t have any more.

Vocabulary.mean: A coach is a person who teaches sports.
Vocabulary.example: My coach gets very excited during games.

Vocabulary.mean: To control something is to make it do what you want.
Vocabulary.example: To control the TV, just push the buttons.

Vocabulary.mean: A description of someone or something says what they are like.
Vocabulary.example: I gave a description of the man with the gun and hat to the police.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is direct, it goes straight between two places.
Vocabulary.example: The green path is a direct route to my house.

Vocabulary.mean: An exam is a test.
Vocabulary.example: I did some practice questions for the math exam on the board.

Vocabulary.mean: An example of something is a thing that is typical of it.
Vocabulary.example: Cola is an example of a soft drink.

Vocabulary.mean: A limit is the largest or smallest amount of something that you allow.
Vocabulary.example: My mother put a limit on how much I could use the phone.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is local, it is nearby.
Vocabulary.example: The local market in my neighborhood sells all the food we need.

Vocabulary.mean: Magical describes a quality that makes someone or something special.
Vocabulary.example: The fireworks made the night sky look so magical.

Vocabulary.mean: Mail is letters and other things sent to people.
Vocabulary.example: I get a lot of mail because I have friends all over the world.

Vocabulary.mean: A novel is a book that tells a story.
Vocabulary.example: He wrote a great novel about ancient China.

Vocabulary.mean: An outline is the plan for a story or essay.
Vocabulary.example: Before I wrote my essay, I made an outline.

Vocabulary.mean: A poet is a person who writes poems.
Vocabulary.example: William Shakespeare was one of the greatest poets.

Vocabulary.mean: To print something is to put it onto paper.
Vocabulary.example: Make sure that you print your name clearly.

Vocabulary.mean: A scene is one part of a book or movie.
Vocabulary.example: A movie is made up of many short pieces or scenes.

Vocabulary.mean: A sheet is a thin flat piece of paper.
Vocabulary.example: I only needed a single sheet of paper to do my homework.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is silly, they show a lack of thought.
Vocabulary.example: I made a silly mistake of dropping mom’s vase.

Vocabulary.mean: A store is a place where you can buy things.
Vocabulary.example: I picked up a few things at the grocery store.

Vocabulary.mean: To suffer is to feel pain.
Vocabulary.example: Her headache made her suffer all day.

Vocabulary.mean: Technology is new things made by using science.
Vocabulary.example: He loves technology such as laptop computers.

Vocabulary.mean: To go across something is to go to the other side of it.
Vocabulary.example: He walked across the board to the other side.

Vocabulary.mean: To breathe means to let air go in and out of your body.
Vocabulary.example: We need strong healthy lungs to help us breathe well.

Vocabulary.mean: A characteristic is something that shows what a person or a thing is like]
Vocabulary.example: One characteristic of tigers is their black stripes.

Vocabulary.mean: To consume something means to eat or drink it.
Vocabulary.example: Jack consumed a whole plate of spaghetti.

Vocabulary.mean: To excite someone means to make them happy and interested.
Vocabulary.example: I heard about the school dance on Friday. This excited me.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is extreme, it is in a large amount or degree.
Vocabulary.example: His workout was so extreme that he was sweating heavily.

Vocabulary.mean: Fear is the feeling of being afraid.
Vocabulary.example: I have a great fear of skateboarding.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are fortunate, you are lucky.
Vocabulary.example: I was fortunate to get a seat.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone happens to do something, they do it by chance.
Vocabulary.example: I happened to meet some new friends at school today.

Vocabulary.mean: The length of something is how long it is from one end to the other.
Vocabulary.example: The length of the floor is three meters.

Vocabulary.mean: A mistake is something you do wrong.
Vocabulary.example: My boss always yells at me when I make a mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: To observe something is to watch it.
Vocabulary.example: Brian observed the sun rising over the mountains.

Vocabulary.mean: An opportunity is a chance to do something.
Vocabulary.example: I had an opportunity to take pictures in the jungle.

Vocabulary.mean: A prize is something of value that is given to the winner.
Vocabulary.example: I won a prize for getting the best grade on my science test.

Vocabulary.mean: A race is a contest to see who is the fastest.
Vocabulary.example: Paul is a fast runner, so he easily won the race.

Vocabulary.mean: To realize is to suddenly understand.
Vocabulary.example: After I left my house, I realized that I left the light on.

Vocabulary.mean: To respond is to give an answer to what someone else said.
Vocabulary.example: When the teacher asked the question, we all responded.

Vocabulary.mean: A risk is a chance of something bad happening.
Vocabulary.example: I took a risk and climbed the snowy mountain.

Vocabulary.mean: To wonder is to ask yourself questions or have a need to know.
Vocabulary.example: The young mother wondered if she’d have a boy or a girl.

Vocabulary.mean: Yet is used to say something has not happened up to now.
Vocabulary.example: We can’t go out yet; we’re still eating.

Vocabulary.mean: An academy is a special type of school.
Vocabulary.example: There are many courses taught at the academy that I go to.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ancient, it is very old.
Vocabulary.example: I want to see the ancient buildings in Rome.

Vocabulary.mean: A board is a flat piece of wood.
Vocabulary.example: The sign was made of a few wooden boards.

Vocabulary.mean: A century is one hundred years.
Vocabulary.example: Our company is celebrating a century of business in London.

Vocabulary.mean: A clue is a fact or object that helps solve a mystery or crime.
Vocabulary.example: The detective found some clues on the sidewalk.

Vocabulary.mean: A concert is an event where you listen to people play music.
Vocabulary.example: I enjoyed the concert last night. The band was very good.

Vocabulary.mean: A county is the largest political division of a state in the US.
Vocabulary.example: He wanted to represent the citizens of his county.

Vocabulary.mean: A dictionary is a book that tells you what words mean.
Vocabulary.example: I use the dictionary to learn new words.

Vocabulary.mean: To exist is to be real.
Vocabulary.example: Do you really think that unicorns ever existed?

Vocabulary.mean: Flat describes something that is level and smooth with no curved parts
Vocabulary.example: My parents bought a new flat screen TV over the weekend.

Vocabulary.mean: A gentleman is a nice man.
Vocabulary.example: My grandfather is a kind and helpful gentleman.

Vocabulary.mean: Hidden means to be not easily noticed or too hard to find.
Vocabulary.example: The hidden camera recorded everything in the parking lot.

Vocabulary.mean: Maybe is used to show that something is possible or may be true.
Vocabulary.example: If I focus hard enough, maybe I can come up with the right answer.

Vocabulary.mean: An officer is a leader in the army.
Vocabulary.example: The soldiers followed the orders of the officer.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is original, it is the first one of that thing.
Vocabulary.example: This is the original painting of the Mona Lisa.

Vocabulary.mean: To pound something is to hit it many times with a lot of force.
Vocabulary.example: He pounded the nail with the hammer.

Vocabulary.mean: A process is the steps to take to do something.
Vocabulary.example: Making a cake is a long process.

Vocabulary.mean: To publish a book is to get it printed and ready to sell.
Vocabulary.example: That company publishes daily newspapers.

Vocabulary.mean: A theater is a building where you watch plays, shows, and movies.
Vocabulary.example: We went to the theater to see a play.

Vocabulary.mean: Wealth is a large amount of money.
Vocabulary.example: One of the most important things to some people is wealth.

Vocabulary.mean: To appreciate something is to understand its good qualities.
Vocabulary.example: I can appreciate the lovely scenery.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is available, it means you can get it.
Vocabulary.example: There were many seats available in the room.

Vocabulary.mean: To beat someone means to do better than they do.
Vocabulary.example: I managed to beat everyone in the race.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is bright, it shows a lot of light.
Vocabulary.example: The bright light from the explosion hurt my eyes.

Vocabulary.mean: To celebrate is to do something to show that an event is special.
Vocabulary.example: We all celebrated when we heard the great news.

Vocabulary.mean: To determine means to choose or make a decision.
Vocabulary.example: He tried to determine which one to eat first.

Vocabulary.mean: To disappear means to go away or not be seen.
Vocabulary.example: The top of the building is disappearing in the clouds.

Vocabulary.mean: If you talk about something else, you talk about something different.
Vocabulary.example: I wanted a bike for my birthday, but I got something else.

Vocabulary.mean: Fair describes treating someone in a way that is reasonable or right.
Vocabulary.example: He sold me his car for a fair price.

Vocabulary.mean: To flow is to move easily and continuously in one direction.
Vocabulary.example: The water flowed over the rocks and into the lake.

Vocabulary.mean: If you move forward, you move in the direction in front of you.
Vocabulary.example: When he saw his mother, the baby crawled forward to her.

Vocabulary.mean: A hill is a round area of land. It is higher than the land around it.
Vocabulary.example: The sun was rising above the green hills.

Vocabulary.mean: A level is a point on a scale that measures something.
Vocabulary.example: Please check the level of the temperature.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is lone, they are the only one of that kind.
Vocabulary.example: A lone man walked along the street.

Vocabulary.mean: A puddle is a pool of liquid on the ground.
Vocabulary.example: When the ice melted, it formed a puddle.

Vocabulary.mean: A response is the answer to a question.
Vocabulary.example: He asked if I was sad. My response was “No. ”

Vocabulary.mean: A season is a time of the year: spring, summer, fall or winter.
Vocabulary.example: Fall is a warm season, while winter is very cold.

Vocabulary.mean: A solution is a way to solve a problem.
Vocabulary.example: There are many problems. We need solutions!

Vocabulary.mean: To waste means to carelessly use something all up.
Vocabulary.example: Turn off the water so you don’t waste it.

Vocabulary.mean: You use whether when you must choose between two things.
Vocabulary.example: I could not decide whether to go left or right.

Vocabulary.mean: To argue is to angrily speak to someone because you do not agree.
Vocabulary.example: We argued about where to go for dinner.

Vocabulary.mean: To communicate is to give information by talking, writing, etc.
Vocabulary.example: I communicated with Paul about his new ideas.

Vocabulary.mean: A crowd is a large group of people.
Vocabulary.example: A large crowd had gathered on the street to see the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To depend on someone or something is to need them.
Vocabulary.example: Children depend on their parents for many things.

Vocabulary.mean: A dish is a plate.
Vocabulary.example: She put a clean white dish on the table.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is empty, it does not have anything in it.
Vocabulary.example: My gas tank was almost empty, so I couldn’t drive my car very long.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is exact, it is just the right amount.
Vocabulary.example: Please use the exact amount of sugar for the cake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fresh, it is new.
Vocabulary.example: I just bought these oranges. They are very fresh.

Vocabulary.mean: To gather is to collect several things usually from different places.
Vocabulary.example: Sam gathered some flowers for his mother.

Vocabulary.mean: To indicate means to show, point or make something clear.
Vocabulary.example: He pointed to his eyes to indicate where he had hurt himself.

Vocabulary.mean: An item is a thing that you buy or sell.
Vocabulary.example: I have many items for school in my bag.

Vocabulary.mean: To offer is to present someone with something.
Vocabulary.example: He offered me the keys to his car.

Vocabulary.mean: The price of something is how much it costs.
Vocabulary.example: What is the price of this item?

Vocabulary.mean: A product is something that is made.
Vocabulary.example: My sister has many beauty products in her room.

Vocabulary.mean: Property is something that someone owns.
Vocabulary.example: The house is now my property.

Vocabulary.mean: To purchase something is to buy it.
Vocabulary.example: I recently purchased a new car.

Vocabulary.mean: To recommend something is to say that someone should do it.
Vocabulary.example: My doctor recommended that I get some exercise.

Vocabulary.mean: To select something is to choose it.
Vocabulary.example: I hope that I selected the right answers on the test.

Vocabulary.mean: A tool is something that helps you do a task.
Vocabulary.example: We used a tool to fix the window.

Vocabulary.mean: To treat is to act in a certain way toward someone.
Vocabulary.example: The cats treated the mouse very nicely.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is alive, they are not dead.
Vocabulary.example: My grandparents are still alive even though they are over 90.

Vocabulary.mean: A bone is a hard part of the body.
Vocabulary.example: I brought home a nice bone for my dog.

Vocabulary.mean: To bother is to make the effort to do something.
Vocabulary.example: No one bothered to wash the dishes today.

Vocabulary.mean: A captain is the person who leads a ship or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: The captain sailed his ship to Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: The conclusion of something is the final part of it.
Vocabulary.example: At the conclusion of the race, the spectators cheered for the winner

Vocabulary.mean: Doubt is a feeling of not being sure.
Vocabulary.example: I have doubt that the story is true.

Vocabulary.mean: To explore is to look for new places.
Vocabulary.example: He wants to explore the world and see new things.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is foreign, it is from a different country.
Vocabulary.example: Mexican food is a popular foreign food.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are glad, you are happy.
Vocabulary.example: I am glad you came to my party.

Vocabulary.mean: However means despite or not being influenced by something.
Vocabulary.example: She is a great cook. However, she never had professional lessons

Vocabulary.mean: Injustice is a lack of fairness or justice.
Vocabulary.example: Putting an innocent person in jail is an act of injustice.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is international, it involves more than one country.
Vocabulary.example: The United Nations is a powerful international organization.

Vocabulary.mean: A lawyer works with the law and represents people in court.
Vocabulary.example: The lawyer left the courthouse after the judge made her decision.

Vocabulary.mean: To mention something is to talk about it.
Vocabulary.example: The doctors mentioned the problems that the patient was having.

Vocabulary.mean: A policy is a rule.
Vocabulary.example: He told us that his policy was to put customers first.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is social, it is about many people in a community.
Vocabulary.example: People should come together and fix the world’s social problems.

Vocabulary.mean: A speech is something said to a group of people.
Vocabulary.example: She gave a speech to the class.

Vocabulary.mean: A staff is a group of people working together in a company.
Vocabulary.example: My dad has a staff of four people to help him at the office.

Vocabulary.mean: If you go toward something, you go closer to it.
Vocabulary.example: Santa walked toward my house with a special tree.

Vocabulary.mean: Wood is the thing that trees are made of.
Vocabulary.example: I put the pieces of wood in a pile.

Vocabulary.mean: To achieve something is to successfully do it after trying hard.
Vocabulary.example: I was happy that I could achieve my goal.

Vocabulary.mean: To advise someone is to tell them what to do.
Vocabulary.example: My mother often advises people about their money.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens already, it happens before a certain time.
Vocabulary.example: It is already time for the movie to start. Let’s go in.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is basic, it is very simple or easy.
Vocabulary.example: I learned some basic English skills in school today.

Vocabulary.mean: A bit is a small amount of something.
Vocabulary.example: I ate a bit of chocolate before I went to bed.

Vocabulary.mean: To consider something means to think about it.
Vocabulary.example: Pete didn’t like his job. He considered getting a new one.

Vocabulary.mean: To destroy means to damage something so badly that it cannot be used.
Vocabulary.example: The glass was destroyed.

Vocabulary.mean: To entertain someone is to do something that they enjoy.
Vocabulary.example: The clown entertained the kids at the party.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is extra, it is more than what is needed.
Vocabulary.example: The squirrel had extra nuts for the winter.

Vocabulary.mean: A goal is something you work toward.
Vocabulary.example: Her goal was to become a doctor.

Vocabulary.mean: To lie is to say or write something untrue to deceive someone.
Vocabulary.example: Whenever Pinocchio lied to his father, his nose grew.

Vocabulary.mean: Meat is food made of animals.
Vocabulary.example: This piece of meat I’m eating tastes very good.

Vocabulary.mean: An opinion is a thought about a person or a thing.
Vocabulary.example: Meg told me her opinion of my story. She said it was not funny.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is real, it actually exists.
Vocabulary.example: The handbag has a stamp on it, so it’s real.

Vocabulary.mean: To reflect is when a surface sends back light, heat, sound or an image.
Vocabulary.example: Her face was reflected on the smooth glass.

Vocabulary.mean: To regard someone or something is to think of them in a certain way.
Vocabulary.example: The boy regarded the girl as a good friend.

Vocabulary.mean: To serve someone is to give them food or drinks.
Vocabulary.example: He served us our drinks quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: A vegetable is a plant used as food.
Vocabulary.example: Carrots are my favorite vegetable.

Vocabulary.mean: A war is a big fight between two groups of people.
Vocabulary.example: Many young men died in the war.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worth an amount of money, it costs that amount.
Vocabulary.example: Our house is worth a lot of money.

Vocabulary.mean: To appear is to seem.
Vocabulary.example: She appeared to be sad. She was crying.

Vocabulary.mean: The base is the bottom of something.
Vocabulary.example: The base of the table has three legs.

Vocabulary.mean: The brain is the organ in your head that lets you think.
Vocabulary.example: You must use your brain to solve the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: A career is a job that you do for a large part of your life.
Vocabulary.example: He was in the hospitality business for most of his career.

Vocabulary.mean: A clerk is a type of worker. Clerks in a store help customers.
Vocabulary.example: The clerk added up her bill for the groceries.

Vocabulary.mean: Effort is hard work or an attempt to do something.
Vocabulary.example: He always puts a lot of effort into his studies.

Vocabulary.mean: To enter a place is to go into it.
Vocabulary.example: Two guards greeted me as I entered the front door.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is excellent, it is very good.
Vocabulary.example: I got an excellent score on my school test.

Vocabulary.mean: A hero is a brave person who does things to help others.
Vocabulary.example: To children, the man in the blue and red costume was a real hero.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurry is to do something quickly.
Vocabulary.example: I hurried home on my bike.

Vocabulary.mean: To inform someone is to tell them about something.
Vocabulary.example: I called and informed her about my idea.

Vocabulary.mean: Later means after the present, expected, or usual time.
Vocabulary.example: She missed the train, so she’ll arrive a little later than expected.

Vocabulary.mean: To leave means to go away from someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: He packed his bag and was ready to leave for home.

Vocabulary.mean: To locate something is to find it.
Vocabulary.example: I could not locate my keys in the house.

Vocabulary.mean: A nurse is a person who helps sick people in the hospital.
Vocabulary.example: A nurse helped me get better.

Vocabulary.mean: An operation is when a doctor replaces or removes something in the body.
Vocabulary.example: The operation on my arm was a success.

Vocabulary.mean: Pain is the feeling that you have when you are hurt.
Vocabulary.example: His head was full of pain.

Vocabulary.mean: To refuse something is to say “no” to it.
Vocabulary.example: The dog refused to play with the cat.

Vocabulary.mean: Though is used when the second idea makes the first seem surprising.
Vocabulary.example: Though he was overweight, he liked to be active.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is various, there are many types of it.
Vocabulary.example: She owned shoes of various styles.

Vocabulary.mean: Actual means that something is real or true.
Vocabulary.example: This is the actual sword that the King owned, not a fake one.

Vocabulary.mean: To amaze someone is to surprise them very much.
Vocabulary.example: The news in the paper amazed Jack.

Vocabulary.mean: A charge is the price to pay for something.
Vocabulary.example: The charge for the shirts was $15.00.

Vocabulary.mean: To comfort someone means to make them feel better.
Vocabulary.example: I wanted to comfort my friend after I heard the bad news.

Vocabulary.mean: To contact someone is to speak or write to them.
Vocabulary.example: I contacted Sue about my party.

Vocabulary.mean: A customer is a person who buys something at a store.
Vocabulary.example: The customer put a few items in a bag.

Vocabulary.mean: To deliver something is to take it from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: The man delivered Chinese food to my house.

Vocabulary.mean: To earn means to get money for the work you do.
Vocabulary.example: He earns his living as a chef in a great restaurant.

Vocabulary.mean: A gate is a type of door. Gates are usually made of metal or wood.
Vocabulary.example: We want to put up a wooden gate around our house.

Vocabulary.mean: To include something means to have it as part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: Does this meal include a soft drink?

Vocabulary.mean: To manage something means to control or be in charge of it.
Vocabulary.example: I had to manage the meeting myself.

Vocabulary.mean: A mystery is something that is difficult to understand or explain.
Vocabulary.example: The path on the map was a complete mystery to me.

Vocabulary.mean: To occur means to happen.
Vocabulary.example: When did the thunderstorm occur?

Vocabulary.mean: If A is the opposite of B, A is completely different from B.
Vocabulary.example: The opposite of black is white.

Vocabulary.mean: A plate is a flat round thing that you put food on.
Vocabulary.example: I put my plate down so I could put some food on it.

Vocabulary.mean: To receive something is to get it.
Vocabulary.example: I received a present on my birthday.

Vocabulary.mean: A reward is something given in exchange for good behavior or work.
Vocabulary.example: He was given a reward for his excellent performance.

Vocabulary.mean: To set something is to put it somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: Please set the dice down on the table.

Vocabulary.mean: To steal is to take something that is not yours.
Vocabulary.example: The men tried to steal money from the bank.

Vocabulary.mean: A thief is someone who quietly takes things that do not belong to them.
Vocabulary.example: A thief broke into our home and took my mother's jewelry.

Vocabulary.mean: To advance is to go forward.
Vocabulary.example: He advanced up the ladder slowly.

Vocabulary.mean: An athlete is a person who plays sports.
Vocabulary.example: Some athletes can play many sports very well.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is average, it is at a normal level.
Vocabulary.example: I’m not rich or poor; I’m average.

Vocabulary.mean: Your behavior is the way you act.
Vocabulary.example: Their behavior was good this semester. They didn’t cause trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: Behind means to be at the back of something.
Vocabulary.example: The little girl was hiding behind a tree.

Vocabulary.mean: A course is a class in school.
Vocabulary.example: I took a P.E. course in school this year.

Vocabulary.mean: To lower something is to make it go down.
Vocabulary.example: The chart shows how his production has lowered over the year.

Vocabulary.mean: To match is to be the same or similar.
Vocabulary.example: The two shoes matched. They looked the same.

Vocabulary.mean: A member is a person who is part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: Julie is the newest member of our team.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mental, it has to do with your mind.
Vocabulary.example: I made a mental picture of the room.

Vocabulary.mean: A passenger is a person who rides in a car, train, or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: One passenger was standing in the subway train.

Vocabulary.mean: Your personality is what you are like and how you behave.
Vocabulary.example: John has a bad personality.

Vocabulary.mean: A poem is a short kind of writing.
Vocabulary.example: William Shakespeare wrote many poems.

Vocabulary.mean: A pole is a long thin stick made of wood or metal that supports things.
Vocabulary.example: The flag was hanging from the flag pole.

Vocabulary.mean: To remove something is to take it away.
Vocabulary.example: I removed the nail from the board.

Vocabulary.mean: Safety means to be the condition of being safe and free from danger.
Vocabulary.example: For his own safety, he was placed in a car seat.

Vocabulary.mean: To shoot is to fire something like a bullet at someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: The hunter raised his gun to shoot at the target.

Vocabulary.mean: To sound means to make a noise.
Vocabulary.example: The alarm clock sounded and woke us all up.

Vocabulary.mean: To swim is to move through water.
Vocabulary.example: I love to swim in the ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: A web is a home made by a spider.
Vocabulary.example: Mom cleaned the spider webs out of the garage.

Vocabulary.mean: A block is a solid piece of wood, stone or ice.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a block of ice on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To cheer is to give a loud shout of approval or encouragement.
Vocabulary.example: The crowd all cheered when the home team won.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is complex, it has many small parts. It is hard to understan
Vocabulary.example: A jigpuzzle can be complex because it has so many pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: A critic is someone who give their opinions about movies, books, plays
Vocabulary.example: The wine critic tasted the wine so he could give his opinion.

Vocabulary.mean: An event is something that happens, especially something important.
Vocabulary.example: Finishing high school was a major event in his life.

Vocabulary.mean: To exercise is to run or play sports so that you can be healthy.
Vocabulary.example: You should exercise every day.

Vocabulary.mean: If something fits, it is small enough orthe right size to go there.
Vocabulary.example: The colorful eggs fit into the box.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendship is the relationship between people who are friends.
Vocabulary.example: Michael and Lisa have a very strong friendship with each other.

Vocabulary.mean: A guide is someone who shows you where to go.
Vocabulary.example: We followed a guide at the park.

Vocabulary.mean: If there is a lack of something, there is not enough of it.
Vocabulary.example: His only problem is a lack of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A passage is a long area with walls that goes from one place to another
Vocabulary.example: The long passage led us to the other side of the field.

Vocabulary.mean: To perform is to do something in front of people who watch.
Vocabulary.example: He will perform a song for the class.

Vocabulary.mean: Pressure is what you apply to make someone do something.
Vocabulary.example: They put pressure on him to change his mind.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is probable, it is likely to happen.
Vocabulary.example: It is probable that you will get a good grade if you study for the test.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is public, it is meant for everyone to use.
Vocabulary.example: I went to the public park to play with my friends.

Vocabulary.mean: To strike someone or something is to hit them.
Vocabulary.example: She struck the other girl in the face.

Vocabulary.mean: To support something is to like it and help it be successful.
Vocabulary.example: Everyone at work supports the new plan.

Vocabulary.mean: A task is work that someone has to do.
Vocabulary.example: Who has the task of building the brick wall?

Vocabulary.mean: A term is a word for something.
Vocabulary.example: I often use the term “oops” when I make a mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: To unite is to get together to do something.
Vocabulary.example: If we unite, we can finish our project faster.

Vocabulary.mean: To associate means to connect something with a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: Most people associate birthday parties with having fun.

Vocabulary.mean: The environment is the place where people work or live.
Vocabulary.example: Keeping our environment clean is important to our health.

Vocabulary.mean: A factory is a building where things are made or put together.
Vocabulary.example: We have only one factory in our town.

Vocabulary.mean: A feature is an important part of something.
Vocabulary.example: The cell phone has many features.

Vocabulary.mean: An instance is an example of something.
Vocabulary.example: I have never experienced an instance of hate. Have you?

Vocabulary.mean: To involve means to be actively taking part in something.
Vocabulary.example: The whole family was involved in playing the game.

Vocabulary.mean: Medicine is something you take to feel better or treat an illness.
Vocabulary.example: The doctor gave me medicine for my cold.

Vocabulary.mean: A mix is different things put together.
Vocabulary.example: The green mix we made in science class spilled onto the table.

Vocabulary.mean: To organize is to plan or get ready for an event.
Vocabulary.example: Make a list to help you organize the things you need.

Vocabulary.mean: A period is an amount of time when something happens.
Vocabulary.example: In one period in Europe, there were many knights.

Vocabulary.mean: If people populate an area, they live there.
Vocabulary.example: Billions of people populate the Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: To produce something is to make or grow it.
Vocabulary.example: This tree produces apples every year.

Vocabulary.mean: A range is a number or a set of similar things.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a range of cars to choose from.

Vocabulary.mean: To recognize something is to know it because you have seen it before.
Vocabulary.example: I recognized an old friend from many years ago.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is regular, it happens often and in equal amounts of time.
Vocabulary.example: Our regular lunch time is around noon.

Vocabulary.mean: A sign is a notice giving information, directions, a warning, etc.
Vocabulary.example: The sign indicated that today would be a bad day.

Vocabulary.mean: A tip is a pointed end of something.
Vocabulary.example: The tip of his pen was very sharp.

Vocabulary.mean: A tradition is something people have been doing for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: Marriage is a tradition all over the world.

Vocabulary.mean: Trash is waste material or unwanted or worthless things.
Vocabulary.example: Please take out the trash; it smells bad.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.
